→ App Design by Association

May 8, 2014 • ∞
1 minute read

Marco Arment on the slow, burning demise of App.net (of note was his perspective on building an app with an existing platform):

Building an app on someone else’s API, rather than making your own, is a huge risk: it usually only pays off if the service provides a huge existing userbase and hard-to-duplicate functionality.

It’s true. Of my major projects at the moment, all rely on the continued existence and stability of their respective “host platforms.” Sifttter Redux needs Day One and IFTTT (not to mention Foursquare, Twitter, etc.) to continue to perform at a high level.1 ExpandSync relies on both aText and TextExpander Touch, both of which seem stable enough. PinPress relies on Pinboard, which, despite an intriguing business model2, carries no guarantees.

That said, these projects have one huge difference compared to App.net: they aren’t trying to make money. If any one of my “relier” services shuts down, despite my sadness, I’ve lost nothing. There was no skin in the game (except for the time I took to develop it, which, truly, is more a gain than a loss).

Perhaps there’s a more fundamental lesson to be learned here. When I peruse any app store and see completely custom, 100% independent apps, I have no problem paying for them. However, when I see yet another Twitter client that costs money, something in me revolts. I immediately start to think, “Is there anything this paid-for app does that the free Twitter app can’t do and will change my life for the better?”

The answer is almost always “no”.

The next question, of course, would be, “Well, Aaron: if someone wanted to pay you for Sifttter Redux, would you do it?” Tricky question, dear reader. Perhaps I wouldn’t be so altruistic after all.

  1. Most of the major services that Sifttter Redux works with aren’t in danger of going away. That said, the service I continually worry about is IFTTT; because services like Zapier exist, how much longer can they continue on a free model? ↩
  2. From Pinboard’s fee explanation page: The fee is based on the formula (number of users * $0.001), so the earlier you join, the less you pay. (source) ↩
